chunks.original_latin: CAPUT VI. De spatio superiore, et paradiso coeli.
chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
<speak>
Chapter  Six<break time="500ms"/>On the Upper Space and the Paradise of Heaven
<break time="1s"/>
</speak>

After discussing the firmament and the lights, there is a vast, empty space that stretches from the firmament of heaven down to the earth. Some writers say this space is divided into two parts: the upper space belongs to heaven, while the lower space is connected to the earth.

The high space that belongs to heaven is very pure and subtle. It has no clouds, no gusts of wind, no rain, no snow or hail, no changes in the air, no storms, or thunder. It doesn't even have the air to support flying birds, clouds, or sustain various living beings with breath. There are no disturbances in the different hemispheres at all.

This is confirmed by those who climb Mount Olympus, the highest peak, unknown to most humans. They report placing sponges soaked in vinegar around their mouths and noses to help them breathe. They ascend annually, driven by some unknown superstition. They say they see no birds, clouds, rain, or wind there. After completing their rituals, they leave marks in the sands and then return. When they climb again the next year, they find these marks undisturbed.

This clearly shows there is no disturbed air there, and nothing related to the greenness of plants or shrubs can be found.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
However, the place we mentioned earlier, that purest and most refined upper space, should not be considered as the actual existence where no earth can reach or approach. Instead, this place pertains to the outermost boundaries of this lower space and the nearby confines of that upper space. In this place, life for those clothed in flesh can by no means dwell.

It is therefore clear that the uppermost, purest, and most tranquil space we discussed earlier, is not meant for those with flesh, nor for mortal things. Many Catholic authors assert that this space was originally designated for the fallen angels and their leader, because they believe no heavenly angel has fallen from above. The celestial angels, while in angelic bliss, did not stay there for a time.

As Scripture says, the devil himself was a liar from the beginning (John 8:44) and did not stand in the truth (First John 3:8). They believe he obtained this place of habitation by lot, with Scripture describing it as a heavenly paradise, speaking under the persona of Prince Cyrus to that highest fallen angel: "You were perfect in beauty, in the delights of the paradise of God" (Ezekiel 28:13).

Just as men, after their sin, were cast out from the happiness of the earthly paradise and thrust into the cursed habitation of this earth, so that while they sinned on earth, they would later live in the abode of an inferior earth under the punishment of their offense, so too, the angels, who are thought to have sinned in the purer space of the air, were miserably and unhappily thrown into a lower place, darker and more turbulent than the very air itself. They are believed to live under the expectation of a future judgment, where they will be more harshly condemned; just as they have airy bodies and now dwell in the air, it is reasonable to think that they once had their seat of beatitude in the air, but in a purer and more refined part.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
However, this place, while it belongs to the firmament of the sky, as I mentioned before, is considered part of the sky, just as the Lord Himself testifies, saying: "I saw Satan fall like lightning from heaven" Luke 10:18. Because of the clear and pure blessedness of that place, Satan was cast out due to his sin and destined for an unhappy and miserable abode in the lower space, that is, the cloudy and stormy air; as the apostle Paul attests, saying: "For our struggle is not against flesh and blood, but against the rulers, against the authorities of this dark world" Ephesians 6:12. Paul also declares that Christ triumphed over these spiritual forces of evil in the heavenly realms in Himself.

Therefore, the evil spirits, along with their leader the devil, having been cast out from that clear dwelling place among the subcelestial spaces that we mentioned, and after the human race was redeemed from the sin of Adam and each individual's own sin through the coming of the Mediator, some think that this same place is now a place of rest for the souls of the saints while they await the future resurrection. They even think it is called the heavenly paradise, about which the Lord said to the thief who confessed on the cross: "Truly I tell you, today you will be with me in paradise" Luke 23:43.

Moreover, in that paradise, planted with trees and endowed with a shining fountain, souls freed from their bodies do not need any material sustenance; indeed, the spiritual person, liberated from the carnal use of the mortal body, does not possess it, nor does he need to be refreshed by the fruit-bearing trees of the earthly paradise. For the eternal does not use the temporal, but contemplates eternal and spiritual things.

We have touched upon these matters not to confirm them but to reflect upon them, especially since we do not attribute to ourselves the clarity of judgment regarding such things.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
<speak>
  When the need arises, we can present all 596 authors of these opinions, to whom either belief or doubt can be attributed. <break time="500ms"/> By addressing their views rather than defending them, we strive to reach the truth. <break time="500ms"/> If a better assertion is present, supported more by examples from Scripture or evaluations from knowledgeable Catholics, we are ready to accept it. <break time="500ms"/> But with the previous matters somewhat explained, let's hasten to the following topics.
</speak>
chunks.original_latin:
Cum enim necessitas exegerit, harum omnium 596 putationum auctores in medium adducere
poterimus, quibus aut fides aut dubitatio
ascribi poterit; quorum referendo potius quam defendendo
(opiniones) laboramus, nos enim alterius
forte melioris, si adsit, assertioni, cui plus vel Scripturae
exempla, vel catholicorum consapientium
(aestimationes) suffragaverint, concordiam subire
parati sumus. Sed de superiore spatio his utcunque
explanatis, ad subsequentia festinemus.
